propositions.text: Shirley Yang comes to see the narrator after not seeing him for some time.
She might have been busy looking for a doctor for Professor Chen or handling the aftermath of the deceased.
The narrator fears being investigated due to the deaths of several people from the archaeological team.
He avoids speaking truthfully about the expedition's dangers.
Four people died, including a teacher and three students, and a professor went mad.
While the narrator is resting at home, Shirley Yang arrives.
She came because Da Jin Ya gave her his address.
Shirley Yang explains her presence.
She is there to return money to the narrator and Fatty.
She plans to take Professor Chen abroad for treatment soon.
She also needs to investigate some matters and will not see them for a while.
The narrator is surprised and pleased to hear about the money.
He tries to decline the money, stating they didn't help much.
He asks if the money is in cash.
Shirley Yang places the money on the table and asks the narrator to promise her something.
The narrator suspects she might want revenge or to dig up his past.
He tries to deflect by joking about rich people's troubles.
Shirley Yang expresses her wish for the narrator to stop being a 'mojin xiaowei' (tomb raider).
She explains that her grandfather quit the profession because it damages one's karma.
She offers to arrange things for them if they visit America.
The narrator objects to the idea of becoming subservient to Shirley Yang.
He believes in the dialectical materialism taught by Chairman Mao, where good can come from bad and vice versa.
He states he has principles and will not touch protected or discovered ancient tombs.
He argues that untouched tombs contain treasures that only those skilled in feng shui can find, and if not found, they would remain lost forever.
He also mentions that environmental changes threaten ancient tombs.
Shirley Yang acknowledges his justifications and states that she won't insist on the money.
The narrator quickly stops her, saying the money is a loan with interest calculated according to the People's Bank of China rates.
Later, Fatty counts the money repeatedly, unable to get the correct amount.
Fatty expresses regret that the narrator called the money a loan, suggesting they flee to their hometown to avoid paying interest.
The narrator dismisses Fatty's concerns, stating that a few successful tomb raids will cover the debt.
He emphasizes the need for capital to buy better equipment and plans a major tomb raid.
The narrator and Fatty agree that finding hidden tombs is difficult and the money might run out.
Fatty, being realistic, suggests opening an antique shop as a potentially profitable venture, especially when selling to foreigners.
He notes that foreigners are becoming savvier but will still pay for genuine good items.
The narrator agrees with Fatty's idea, recognizing the potential for profit and the opportunity to learn about antique appraisal.
They search for a shop but find none suitable, deciding to start by setting up a stall in Panjiyuan.
Panjiyuan is characterized by its wide variety of items, though truly valuable artifacts are rare and privately traded.
Following Da Jin Ya's advice, they start by collecting small items from the Qing Dynasty in the suburbs, such as bowls, jars, coins, snuff bottles, and old watches.
The narrator admits he is not suited for selling, misjudging items and losing money.
He acknowledges that he bought worthless items as treasures and sold valuable ones as ordinary objects.
Despite the losses, they consider the experience valuable for honing their eyes and gaining knowledge.
They realize the antique trade is complex, even more so than feng shui.
One day, the antique market is quiet, and the narrator, Fatty, and Da Jin Ya are playing cards.
A man approaches their stall, lingering without browsing.
Fatty asks if he's looking for anything.
The man hesitantly asks if they buy antiques.
The narrator observes the man: around 37 years old, with reddish-purple skin from sun exposure, dressed rustically, carrying a worn leather bag, and speaking with a dusty accent.
The narrator doubts the man has any valuable antiques and exchanges a look with Da Jin Ya.
Da Jin Ya, being an expert, signals the narrator to engage the man and find out more.
The narrator offers the man a cigarette and invites him to sit.
The man, unaccustomed to such hospitality, sits cautiously, clutching his bag.
The narrator wonders if the man is a tomb raider or if his bag contains something valuable.
He asks for the man's name in a gentle tone.
The man introduces himself as Li Chunlai.
He seems more relaxed squatting on the ground.
Da Jin Ya and Fatty pretend to continue their card game, adhering to the unspoken rule of not having too many people present during a negotiation.
The narrator asks Li Chunlai if he has any artifacts to sell.
Li Chunlai asks, "What artifact?"
The narrator clarifies, asking if he has antiques to sell and if he can see them.
Li Chunlai whispers that he has a shoe and asks how much they would pay.
The narrator is initially annoyed but suspects there's more to it and patiently asks about the shoe.
Li Chunlai cautiously shows an embroidered shoe for a three-inch golden lotus foot from ancient times inside his bag.
The narrator wants to examine the shoe more closely and asks where he got it.
Li Chunlai insists on a price first.
The narrator suggests going to a nearby restaurant to discuss the sale over dumplings.
Li Chunlai agrees, eager for the dumplings.
They go to a well-known lamb dumpling restaurant.
The owner leads them to a private room in the back.
The narrator assures Li Chunlai of the privacy and asks to see the shoe again.
Li Chunlai is distracted by the smell of dumplings.
The narrator gently urges him to focus, mentioning that a good price for the shoe could fund many such meals.
Li Chunlai expresses his desire to marry and have children with the money.
They discuss marriage customs and the attractiveness of women from Mizhi.
The dumplings arrive, and Li Chunlai eats heartily.
The narrator orders more dumplings and offers Li Chunlai vinegar and beer as alternatives to sour soup dumplings.
After Li Chunlai finishes eating, the narrator brings up the shoe again.
Li Chunlai, now trusting, shows the embroidered shoe.
The narrator examines the shoe: small, pointed, with green satin base, embroidered with peonies, and a sandalwood sole with a hidden compartment for spices.
He dates it to the Ming Dynasty based on its appearance and embroidery.
He notes the shoe's high craftsmanship, suggesting it belonged to a woman from a wealthy family who practiced foot binding.
While not as skilled as Da Jin Ya, the narrator believes the shoe is not a fake and is a valuable collectible.
Li Chunlai recounts the story of his village's drought and their attempts to appease the weather gods.
A blind fortune teller claimed a 'Hanba' (drought demon) was causing the drought and needed to be killed.
A boy reported seeing a green-skinned child enter an ownerless, unfurried coffin in an abandoned graveyard.
The fortune teller identified this as the location of the Hanba.
The villagers decided to open the coffin.
The village chief disagreed, but the fortune teller made a bet with him.
They opened the coffin, revealing a putrid smell and a well-preserved female corpse dressed in ancient clothing.
On top of the corpse was a small, green-furred, monkey-like creature, which was alive.
The fortune teller declared the creature to be the Hanba and insisted it be beaten and burned quickly.
Villagers captured and beat the creature, which emitted black gas instead of blood.
The creature was then burned to ashes.
The fortune teller advised burning the corpse and its belongings.
As the villagers hesitated, dark clouds gathered, and thunder was heard.
The villagers, now convinced of the fortune teller's claims, decided to burn the coffin.
Li Chunlai was tasked with setting the coffin on fire.
He quickly gathered firewood and set the coffin ablaze.
Li Chunlai, a poor bachelor, felt tempted by the treasures inside the coffin.
Suddenly, lightning struck, and heavy rain extinguished the fire, leaving the coffin half-burned.
Li Chunlai saw this as an opportunity to retrieve the valuables.
He found the coffin lid easy to open due to the fire damage.
He braced himself to look inside and retrieve jewelry.
The smell from the burned and rain-soaked corpse was unbearable.
As Li Chunlai reached for a gold bracelet, someone clapped him on the back, startling him.
It turned out to be Ma Shun, known for his bravery and recklessness.
Ma Shun had also seen the jewelry and, seeing an opportunity, returned to steal it.
Ma Shun stripped the corpse of its valuables, gave Li Chunlai one shoe as hush money, and warned him not to speak of it.
They then buried the coffin together.
Upon returning to the village, they lied about burning the coffin and corpse.
The fortune teller explained that the situation might have been a mother and child becoming dangerous zombies ('zi mu xiong').
Li Chunlai felt uneasy but kept quiet.
That night, Li Chunlai dreamt of the corpse and her son trying to choke him.
The next morning, Ma Shun's house was struck by lightning, killing him and his family.
The villagers found the stolen treasures at Ma Shun's house, and the village chief forced Li Chunlai to confess.
Li Chunlai, though scared, didn't reveal he had kept a shoe and blamed Ma Shun.
The narrator discusses the history and nature of 'zombies' (dazongzi in their profession).
A proper burial in a good feng shui location benefits the deceased and their descendants.
Conversely, unsuitable burial sites can cause unrest for the deceased and harm others.
Unsuitable burial sites can be due to geographical hazards (mountainous or watery, chaotic terrain) or specific tomb placements.
A key concept in feng shui is the interplay of 'xing' (form, referring to terrain) and 'shi' (momentum, referring to the state of the terrain).
When 'xing' and 'shi' are in conflict, it leads to imbalances in the earth's energy, resulting in phenomena like undecomposed corpses turning into zombies.
Fatty finds the theory interesting but dismisses it as a joke.
Da Jin Ya is more interested and inquires about the details.
He laments the scarcity of good feng shui locations due to China's long history and numerous imperial burials.
The narrator explains that China has numerous 'dragon脉' (veins of mountains), but only a few are suitable for burials.
Kunlun Mountain is considered the origin of all dragon脉.
Dragon脉 have various qualities, such as 'chen long' (submerged dragon), 'qian long' (hidden dragon), 'fei long' (flying dragon), and others.
Only the highest quality dragon脉 can be used for royal burials.
Da Jin Ya questions the efficacy of feng shui, citing Qin Shi Huang's tomb and the short-lived Qin Dynasty.
The narrator acknowledges that feng shui is only one factor and that historical outcomes are not solely determined by it.
He suggests that natural changes (earthquakes, floods, etc.) can alter the feng shui of a site, turning a auspicious location into an inauspicious one.
They decide to postpone their antique business and plan a trip to Shaanxi to collect antiques.
They travel by train to Taiyuan.
In Taiyuan, they hear news of a flood in the Yellow River, which has exposed many ancient tombs in the Zhuangling area.
They change their plan and decide to travel west across the Yellow River.
Their long-distance bus breaks down, causing a significant delay.
The bus stops near the Yellow River, and the driver suggests they try to find a boat there to cross.
They get off the bus to wait for a boat, but the area is desolate.
They are dismayed by the width and ferocity of the Yellow River, realizing the usual crossing points might be submerged.
As it starts to rain, they share liquor and beef jerky, complaining about the bus driver.
The narrator recalls seeing sheepskin rafts used for crossing the river in his military days.
They continue to wait in the rain.
Feeling frustrated, the narrator shouts into the roaring river.
Fatty and Da Jin Ya join him in shouting, and they drink more liquor.
Fatty suggests singing local folk songs.
The narrator jokes about Fatty's lack of knowledge of local customs and offers to sing Qinqiang opera.
Fatty argues that they should sing the appropriate song for the location, referencing a proverb about drinking Yellow River water and singing 'Xintianyou'.
The narrator dismisses the proverb and quotes a poem about drinking water from Changsha and eating Wuchang fish.
Da Jin Ya intervenes, suggesting they each sing a song of their choice.
Fatty prepares to sing, but a motorboat approaches.
They signal the boat to come ashore.
The boatman is clearly a local, and after some negotiation and payment, they board the boat.

concepts.name: Shirley Yang
concepts.context: Character who returns money and makes a request.

concepts.name: Professor Chen
concepts.context: Person needing medical treatment abroad.

concepts.name: Archaeological team
concepts.context: Group involved in an expedition with casualties.

concepts.name: Mojin Xiaowei
concepts.context: A profession related to tomb raiding.

concepts.name: Da Jin Ya
concepts.context: Introduces people, an expert in antiques.

concepts.name: Fatty
concepts.context: Narrator's companion, practical and concerned with money.

concepts.name: Antique collecting
concepts.context: Activity of acquiring old objects for value.

concepts.name: Feng Shui
concepts.context: Chinese art of geomancy, influencing burial and building sites.

concepts.name: Tomb raiding
concepts.context: The act of entering and taking items from tombs.

concepts.name: Ancient tombs
concepts.context: Burial sites from past eras.

concepts.name: Treasures
concepts.context: Valuable items found in ancient tombs.

concepts.name: Panjiyuan
concepts.context: A place where antiques are sold, often informally.

concepts.name: Antiques
concepts.context: Objects from the past valued for their age or rarity.

concepts.name: Li Chunlai
concepts.context: A villager who offers an ancient shoe for sale.

concepts.name: Ancient shoe
concepts.context: The item of interest brought by Li Chunlai.

concepts.name: Hanba
concepts.context: A mythical creature associated with drought.

concepts.name: Corpse
concepts.context: A dead body, often ancient in this context.

concepts.name: Coﬃn
concepts.context: A container for a dead body.

concepts.name: Zombies
concepts.context: Reanimated corpses, a concept in their profession.

concepts.name: Dragon脉
concepts.context: Lines of mountains considered to have auspicious energy for burial.

concepts.name: Yellow River
concepts.context: A major river in China, a setting for a significant event.

concepts.name: Flood
concepts.context: An event causing damage and revealing ancient sites.

concepts.name: Shaanxi
concepts.context: A province in China, a destination for the characters.

main_topics: The nature of Mojin Xiaowei and tomb raiding
The journey and challenges of the protagonists
hierarchy.structure: The document follows a chronological narrative, interweaving character dialogue and actions with explanations of relevant concepts and the unfolding plot. It begins with a personal encounter, moves to a business venture, and then delves into a historical anecdote and a geographical journey, all driven by the protagonists' pursuit of artifacts and adventure.
